title: How can tablets and devices be used as a responsible tool between parents and children? - Quora

response.answer_text: You have to think beyond it’s a device and entertainment purposes. They use them in school. Even preschools. My daughter has been using an iPad in school since preschool. They can be very educational. I would recommend finding a “children’s” tablet/device. It doesn’t come with all the bells and whistles as a regular one does. It’s strictly made for kids. Easier to monitor access. On my seven year olds, she doesn’t even have the ability to chat, google, search other internet engines, etc. With COVID and school buildings closes, that’s how she did school was online. Plus the learning is fun and not so rigid. At the beginning of the school year, her teacher(s) usually give us a list of recommended educational sites they use in the classroom as well. When my daughter was 3, I downloaded ABC Mouse for her. She loves Science and Math. Those are my two worst subjects. At age three, she was telling me all about pyramids, planets, animals I didn’t even know about. Some of that stuff I had to look up myself.

My daughter is 14. She doesn’t have a phone, iPad, or any sort of device. We have laptops, iPads at home but she has to use them with permission and they stay downstairs. She plays games on them for about 40 minutes per day. Instead of this for entertainment, we play board games. We are really competitive and spend hours doing these things. We bake, cook, and read. My daughter reads at the YA level, 1 book every two days. I would hate to see her waste her life behind a phone chatting away. She has friends that come over or she can socialize with them at school. Just because you can afford them, doesn’t mean that children to have them. They need to be able to do things that do not require a device.

Because we might as well face reality (that some here deny) that technology is the future, and frankly the future is now. Young people should have their own technological devices (especially when trying to research something for a class project or some such assignment). Mr Google, as a friend of mine calls it, is very handy when you’re stumped. Heck the internet wasn’t even a thing until I was in college and it took forever for my parents to let us have it at home, but it would have made my life in middle and high school a LOT simpler

I can’t think of any reason why a child should be given the use of “devices” because the parents can afford it. Seems like a silly reason to me. If the parents want to provide the use of devices for their children, they should make it clear that the child doesn’t “own” them but that the parents do and are allowing the child to use them, and that permission can be withdrawn.
They shouldn’t before the age of twelve if you can help it at all because they don’t know how to manage it, and there’s a lot of content out there that children much younger than that can’t handle.
